tei:dateline.tei:note: The first semester began, as usual, in early October. According to his diary, Schenker informed his pupils of their lesson times on September 28 and started teaching by October 3.

tei:div.tei:ab: Bach: Prelude & Fugue in E minor, new; Mozart: Piano Concerto in A major; Brahms: Waltz[es?]; Schubert: Impromptus and Musical Moments: A major, A major, F minor, C minor, F minor.

op. 101,Schenker's Erläuterungsausgabe of Beethoven's Piano Sonata Op. 101 (published August 1921) includes a substantial analysis that was, according to his diary, dictated in part on 19 October 1919 and completed on 20 June 1920 ‒ thus during the 1919/20 saison. neu, Mitte Januar abgeschlossen; Chaconne-OppelPresumably this was the Chaconne enclosed in Reinhard Oppel's letter to Schenker from 7 September 1919. The letter survives (OJ 13/10 [7]), but the Chaconne is missing.; Schubert: Müller-Lieder (vgl. mit Wächter,In September 1919, Eberhard von Wächter gave Schenker two copies of a book on Schubert that he had written (see diary entries for September 13, 16, and 20). Presumably this was Wächter's monograph Franz Schuberts Liederzyklus "Die schöne Müllerin": Eine anaytisch-kritische Studie (Leipzig: C.F.W. Siegel, 1919). 28.I. zuende). Schubert: Impromtus: Asd, Gd.
Op. 101, new, completed in the middle of January; Oppel Chaconne; Schubert: Müller-Lieder (compare to Wächter, completed January 28). Schubert: Impromptus: A major, G major

strenger Satz; Appassionata; zum Lied als Beispiel Schuberts „Ihr Bild”This song was the subject of an unpublished analysis by Schenker dating from ca. 1906 (OC 31/436) and of a well-known article in the first issue of Der Tonwille (1921). According to Schenker's diary, he submitted the latter analysis to Universal Edition on 10 November 1920; zum Generalbass einige erste Worte; zur Fuge einige erste Worte; Mozart: Sonate Am.
Strict composition; "Appassionata"; on the Lied, with Schubert's "Ihr Bild" as an example; a few initial words on thoroughbass; a few initial words on fugue; Mozart: Sonata in A minor.
Mozart: Sonate Ad; Beethoven: Son. Ad.
Mozart: Sonata in A major; Beethoven: Sonata in A major.

tei:div.tei:head: Gärtner::
tei:div.tei:ab: Kontrapunkt Fortsetzung, 4-stimmiger Satz u. MischungsgattungOn combination-types (i.e., combinations of the five species of strict counterpoint), see Bridges to Free Composition in Schenker, Counterpoint, Book 2..
Further study of counterpoint: four-part counterpoint and combination-types.

Vorbereitung zum KonzertSchenker's diary suggests the concert took place on 5 November 2019: "An Hupka (pn. K.): beglückwünsche ihm zum ersten Abend u. erkläre ihm, weshalb ich doch nicht erschienen bin." ("To Hupka (pneumatic postcard): congratulate him on the first evening and explain why I wasn't there after all.") Presumably the concert took place at the Wiener Konzerthaus, as this was the location of a rehearsal that Schenker attended on 3 November. Exceptionally, Hupka was permitted to begin his lessons early, on September 23, because of his upcoming concert.; neu:
Brahms: Konzert Dm; Beethoven: op. 81; Schumann: Etude symphonique (beg. 27.I.);
Chromatische Fantasie, neu; wiederholt: Chopin: Nocturne; neu: Beethoven Sonate Dm ‒ nach dem 1. Satz ausgesprungen.
Chromatic Fantasy, new; revisited: Chopin: Nocturne; new: Beethoven Sonata in D minor ‒ gave up after the first movement.

wiederholt: op. 109, Chopin: Nocturne Esd, op. 101,Schenker's Erläuterungsausgabe of Beethoven's Op. 101 (published August 1921) includes a substantial analysis that was, according to his diary, dictated in part on 19 October 1919 and completed on 20 June 1920—thus during the 1919/20 saison. Berceuse, sämtliche Chopin-Etudes op. 10; Fragen aus Beethovens Pathetique; wiederholt Chopins Etudes op. 25; neu: Schubert: Impromtus u. Moments; Fragen aus Chopin Nocturne Hd; wiederholt Waldstein-Sonate, Brahms-Händel-Variationen, Beethoven Cm-Variationen, Brahms: Walzer, Beethoven: Mondschein-Sonate.

Revisited: Op. 109, Chopin: Nocturne in E major, Op. 101, Berceuse, complete Chopin Etudes Op. 10; questions on Beethoven's "Pathétique"; revisited: Chopin's Etudes Op. 25; new: Schubert: Impromptus and Moments [Musicaux]; questions on Chopin's Nocturne in B major; revisited: "Waldstein" Sonata, Brahms Handel Variations, Beethoven Variations in C minor, Brahms: Waltzes?, Beethoven: "Moonlight" Sonata.

wiederholt: Beethoven-Variationen Cm; Brahms: Intermezzo Cd, Chopin: zwei Préludes, Etude Cm aus op. 10; Brahms:
Walzer, neu; wiederholt: Appassionata, Sonate Dm; Bach: Esm Präludium, neuA brief diary entry from March 10, 1920 suggests that Schenker's analysis of this piece, published in Tonwille 1 (1921), was underway during the 1919/20 saison: "Korrektur des Es moll-Präludiums" ("Corrections to the Prelude in E minor").; Variation serieus, Mendelssohn, neu.

Revisited: Beethoven Variations in C minor; Brahms: Intermezzo in C major, Chopin: two Preludes, Etude in C minor from Op. 10; Brahms:
Waltzes?, new; revisited: "Appassionata," Sonata in D minor; Bach: Prelude in E minor, new; Variation serieus, Mendelssohn, new.

Kontrapunkt; Harmonielehre, dazu Beispiele aus op. 101Schenker's Erläuterungsausgabe of Beethoven's Op. 101 (published August 1921) includes a substantial analysis that was, according to his diary, dictated in part on 19 October 1919 and completed on 20 June 1920 ‒ thus during the 1919/20 saison., Schubert, Mozart: Sonate Am.
Counterpoint; theory of harmony, with examples from Op. 101, Schubert, Mozart: Sonata in A minor.
Brahms-Händel-Variationen, neu (abgeschl. Mitte Januar). Bach: Präludium u. Fuge Cm, neu; Beethoven: Appassionata wiederholt, Mondschein-Sonate, neu; Bach: Präludium u. Fuge Cisd.

Brahms, Handel Variations, new (completed in the middle of January). Bach: Prelude & Fugue in C minor, new; Beethoven: "Appassionata" revisited, "Moonlight" Sonata, new; Bach: Prelude & Fugue in C major
Bach: Präludium u. Fuge Cm, neu; wiederholt: Mondschein-Sonate u. Etudes von Chopin: Fd, Gesd.
Bach: Prelude & Fugue in C minor, new; revisited: "Moonlight" Sonata and Etudes by Chopin: F major, G major
Kreutzer-Sonate; Mozart: Klavier-Violin-Sonate Bd; Chopin: Polonaise Asd wiederholt.
"Kreutzer" Sonata; Mozart: Sonata for Piano and Violin in B major; Chopin: Polonaise in A major revisited.

Kontrapunkt Fortsetzung; Schubert:
Phantasie-Sonate Gd.

Further study of counterpoint; Schubert:
Fantasy-Sonata in G major.
